item.title: Your Questions, My Answers on Stanford’s Graduate AI Certification
item.dc:creator: ross
item.description: I have been asked a lot of questions lately about Stanford’s online course offerings and why somebody would choose them over myriad of options online. This is my attempt to bundle them together to help a broader audience. 1. How do you choose classes? It depends on your goals and interests. Here are some questions […]
item.content:encoded:
I have been asked a lot of questions lately about Stanford’s online course offerings and why somebody would choose them over myriad of options online. This is my attempt to bundle them together to help a broader audience.

1. How do you choose classes?
It depends on your goals and interests. Here are some questions to ask.

  • Goal:Â 
    • What do you want to achieve out of a particular course?Â 
    • Are you learning for fun or do you want to apply the knowledge to build something?
    • Do you want to extend/switch careers to become a Deep Learning practitioner?
    • Do you think these tools will help you solve a real-life problem?
  • Interests:
    • Read through the course page, find out the topics they cover and search for applications/projects related to it. Do these topics interest you? Here is my review on some of the classes to help you get started.

2. Reference Materials for classes?

  • Most classes at Stanford are self-contained but you are welcomed to read and research resources, there is tons of literature on most topics as it’s an active field of research.Â 
  • Teaching staff usually provides references for each topic which help you consolidate concepts.

3. Are there any forums to discuss doubts? Is there any form of Mentorship provided?

  • There are Course Assistants for every class and there is also a forum setup per class where you can discuss doubts and ask questions to help solidify your understanding.Â 
  • You are also assigned a Mentor for your project which is one of the course assistants for the class. They help give feedback and suggestions to help you navigate and sketch out scope of a project.
4. What can you get out of a class project?

  • A class project can be an open research problem, your attempt at reproducing ideas presented in a paper or simply applying fundamentals to a real-life problem. This is one of the most interesting parts of the courses which helps you exercise what you have learnt and even explore beyond the class.Â 
  • Choosing challenging course projects helps you explore and become better at applying concepts and figure out how to use these tools in real-life problems.

5. What Programming Language is preferred?

  • Most classes require you to code in Python.Â 

6. Why is it still worth taking the course when you have online courses at a much lower cost?

  • These are actual “Graduate” courses taken by students at Stanford. I have found them to be quite challenging but at the same time rewarding in ways that broaden your horizon and knowledge with State-of-the-Art (SoTA) literature and techniques.Â 
  • I would suggest using other online courses as basics to build upon with these Graduate level classes.Â 



7. Why one shouldn’t one beÂ judgmentalÂ about this course since it is a “Graduate Certificate” unlike a full time Master’s course?

  • Graduate level courses are more abstract compared to their undergraduate counterparts. Again, It depends on what your goals are, if you have a Master’s you can update yourself with these classes.Â 
  • On the other hand, my understanding is that the same courses can be taken as part of an online Master’s program.

item.title: Review : Stanford’s Online Artificial Intelligence Courses – Deep Learning and Machine Learning
item.dc:creator: ross
item.description: Hello! I have been enrolled at Stanford and have been taking their courses online. Here are my few cents on the ones I have taken so far. CS224n – Natural Language Processing with Deep Learning (Prof. Manning) Difficulty: 4/5 (Moderate) What to expect:Â Get exposed to State-of-the-Art (SoTA) Deep Learning techniques applied to NLP. Key […]
item.content:encoded:
Hello!



I have been enrolled at Stanford and have been taking their courses online. Here are my few cents on the ones I have taken so far.

CS224n – Natural Language Processing with Deep Learning (Prof. Manning)

  • Difficulty: 4/5 (Moderate)
  • What to expect:Â 
    • Get exposed to State-of-the-Art (SoTA) Deep Learning techniques applied to NLP. Key topics:Â 
      • Question and Answering
      • Text Summarization
      • Parts of Speech tagging
      • Sequence-to-Sequence models
      • Transformers
    • Gives you a very good overview of where NLP is headed, homeworks are challenging but allow you to implement latest neural architectures to solve various language problems.
  • My class project: BertQAÂ (99* stars on github) – Won Best Project Award in the class

CS231n –Â Convolutional Neural Networks for Visual Recognition (Prof. Li and Justin Johnson)

  • Difficulty: 4/5 (Moderate)
  • What to expect:Â 
    • Extensive overview of latest trends in Computer Vision techniques across different domains and applications –Â 
      • Discriminative models
      • Unsupervised techniques
      • Neural Architecture layers and intutionsÂ 
      • Segmentation
      • Generative Techniques
      • Style Transfer
    • Homeworks are the best part of the class which allow you to implement a variety of Neural Layers and get in-depth intuition of how deep learning actually works.
    • I would suggest some familiarity with matrix calculus and probability for this course.
  • My class project:Â Spatio-Temporal Adversarial Video Super Resolution

CS221 – Artificial Intelligence – Principles and Techniques (Prof. Liang and Prof. Sadigh)
  • Difficulty: 4.5/5 (Heavy)
  • What to expect:Â 
    • This is one of the most “dense” classes I have come across at Stanford. The nature of the class is such that it is trying to fit in this huge umbrella of AI topics within a quarter – which is what makes it challenging. Topics include –Â 
      • Search
      • Markov Decision Process
      • Reinforcement Learning (RL)
      • Adversarial Games
      • Constraint Satisfaction problems
      • Bayesian Networks (BN)
    • Amongst these, Reinforcement Learning and Bayesian Networks are conceptually heavy topics which require some extra effort.
    • That being said, the topics are interesting and makes you appreciate the latest trends in AI and draw parallels from traditional techniques.Â 
    • Homeworks are weekly and can take time but are fun for the most part! You build your own Pacman game.Â 
  • My class project:Â 
    • Work in progress (to be updated shortly)
Feel free to send in any other questions you would like for me to answer.
Thank you,
Ankit Chadha

item.title: Unleashing Creativity with Procreate and Apple Pencil: A Comprehensive Guide
item.dc:creator: sawberries
item.description: Introduction: In the world of digital art, the combination of Procreate and the Apple Pencil has emerged as a powerhouse duo, offering unparalleled precision, versatility, and a natural drawing experience. Whether youâ€™re a seasoned artist or a beginner eager to explore your creative potential, this guide will walk you through the essentials of using Procreate […]
item.content:encoded:
• byÂ Post Box
  • 1 Comment

Introduction:

In the world of digital art, the combination of Procreate and the Apple Pencil has emerged as a powerhouse duo, offering unparalleled precision, versatility, and a natural drawing experience. Whether youâ€™re a seasoned artist or a beginner eager to explore your creative potential, this guide will walk you through the essentials of using Procreate with an Apple Pencil, helping you to unlock new dimensions of digital artistry.

Getting Started: Setting the Stage

Before diving into the vibrant world of digital painting and drawing, ensure you have the latest version of Procreate installed on your iPad and your Apple Pencil fully charged. Procreate supports both first and second-generation Apple Pencils, providing a seamless experience across various iPad models.

Pairing Your Apple Pencil

  1. First-Generation Apple Pencil: Plug it into the Lightning port of your iPad to pair.
  2. Second-Generation Apple Pencil: Attach it magnetically to the side of your compatible iPad Pro or iPad Air for automatic pairing.

Navigating the Procreate Interface

Familiarize yourself with the Procreate interface. Key areas include the Gallery (where your artworks are stored), the canvas (your digital paper), and the Brushes, Layers, and Colors panels, which are instrumental in creating your art. Spend some time exploring these features to understand how they interact with the Apple Pencilâ€™s capabilities.

Leveraging Apple Pencilâ€™s Features

Pressure Sensitivity: The Apple Pencilâ€™s pressure sensitivity is brilliantly exploited by Procreate to mimic the behavior of real-life art tools. Press harder for thicker lines or more intense colors, and use a lighter touch for fine, delicate strokes.

Tilt Functionality: Tilting your Apple Pencil changes the character of your strokes, simulating the effect of shading with the side of a lead pencil or broadening the stroke of a paintbrush, adding depth and texture to your work.

Palm Rejection: Procreate and the Apple Pencil work together to offer an exceptional palm rejection feature. This means you can rest your hand on the screen comfortably as you draw, without worrying about unwanted marks.

Tips for Maximizing Your Creativity

  • Customize Your Brushes: Dive into the brush settings to tweak their properties, or create your own custom brushes to suit your style.
  • Explore Layers: Use layers to separate elements of your artwork, making it easier to edit and adjust without affecting the entire piece.
  • Practice with Gestures: Learn Procreateâ€™s gesture controls to speed up your workflow. Undo, redo, zoom, and navigate your canvas with intuitive finger movements.
  • Stay Inspired: Regularly explore new techniques, tutorials, and the vast library of resources available within the Procreate community. The app is continually updated with new features, so thereâ€™s always something new to learn.

Conclusion

The synergy between Procreate and the Apple Pencil offers an exceptional platform for digital artists to explore and express their creativity. By mastering the basics and continually experimenting with new techniques, you can unlock the full potential of this dynamic duo, pushing the boundaries of whatâ€™s possible in digital art. Whether youâ€™re sketching, painting, or illustrating, Procreate and the Apple Pencil will become indispensable tools in your creative arsenal. Happy creating!

Remember, the journey of art is endless and filled with continuous learning. Embrace each stroke, each layer, and every color blend as a step towards mastering the art of digital creativity with Procreate and Apple Pencil.
